Description: The foundational background color for the entire page in dark mode. Use a dark gray rather than pure black to reduce eye strain and allow elevation hierarchy.
Do: Use #121212 or #0A0A0A as the base surface color, providing a soft dark foundation
Don't: Use pure #000000 as your base background — it creates harsh contrast and eliminates elevation hierarchy

Description: Elevated surfaces like cards and panels should be lighter than the base to communicate depth. Use white overlay at low opacity on the base color.
Do: Use #1E1E1E or #1C1C1E for elevated surfaces (cards/sheets/drawers) creating a subtle lift from the base
Don't: Use the same background for all surface levels — everything looks flat and users cannot distinguish hierarchy

Description: Modal and dialog overlays need a semi-transparent dark backdrop to focus attention and indicate a layer above the main content.
Do: Use a semi-transparent black overlay like rgba(0/0/0/0.6) for modals and #2C2C2E or zinc-800 for the modal surface itself
Don't: Use a fully opaque overlay that completely hides the content beneath or skip the overlay entirely on modals

Description: Cards should feel elevated from the base surface with a subtle background shift. The difference should be perceptible but not jarring.
Do: Use #1A1A1A to #1E1E1E for card backgrounds roughly 1-2 steps lighter than the base surface
Don't: Use borders alone without any background difference — cards blend into the base and lose visual grouping

Description: On OLED screens pure black (#000000) pixels are truly off saving battery. Offer an optional OLED mode with pure black base while keeping the default at #121212.
Do: Offer an optional OLED/AMOLED mode that uses #000000 for the base surface while keeping #121212 as the default dark mode
Don't: Force pure black as the only dark mode option — it creates harsh contrast and removes elevation cues for non-OLED users

Description: Primary text in dark mode should not be pure white. Use a slightly off-white to reduce glare and eye fatigue while maintaining strong readability.
Do: Use #E5E5E5 or #F2F2F2 for primary body text ensuring at least 15.4:1 contrast on #121212
Don't: Use pure #FFFFFF for body text — it causes halation and eye strain against dark backgrounds especially for users with astigmatism

Description: Secondary text conveys supporting information and should be visually subordinate to primary text. Use reduced opacity or a mid-gray tone.
Do: Use #A1A1AA (zinc-400) or #9CA3AF for secondary text maintaining at least 4.5:1 contrast ratio on dark surfaces
Don't: Use a gray too close to the background (below 4.5:1 contrast) making secondary text unreadable in dark mode

Description: Disabled and placeholder text should clearly indicate non-interactivity while still being minimally legible for context.
Do: Use #52525B (zinc-600) or text-zinc-500 for disabled text achieving approximately 3:1 contrast — intentionally below AA for body but meeting AA for large text
Don't: Use near-invisible text like zinc-800 on zinc-950 backgrounds — users cannot discern what the disabled element represents

Description: Links need to stand out from surrounding text in dark mode. Desaturated blues or light accent colors work well without being too vibrant.
Do: Use a desaturated light blue like #60A5FA (blue-400) for links ensuring clear differentiation from body text and sufficient contrast
Don't: Use saturated bright blue (#0000FF or blue-600) which vibrates against dark backgrounds and causes eye fatigue
Code Example Bad: <a class='dark:text-blue-600'> /* low contrast on dark bg */

Description: When placing text on colored backgrounds (badges/chips/banners) ensure adequate contrast by pairing light text with dark tints or dark text with light tints.
Do: Test contrast ratios for every text-on-color combination; use light text (#F2F2F2) on dark-tinted badges and dark text (#1A1A1A) on light-tinted badges
Don't: Assume light text works on all colored backgrounds — medium-brightness colors like yellow or lime often fail contrast checks with white text

Description: Brand and primary colors that look great on white backgrounds often feel neon and harsh on dark. Reduce saturation by 20-30% or shift to a lighter tint for dark mode.
Do: Shift primary colors to the 300-400 range in dark mode (e.g. blue-600 in light becomes blue-400 in dark) reducing vibrancy while preserving brand identity
Don't: Keep the same saturated primary color from light mode — it appears neon and causes visual vibration and fatigues the eyes on dark backgrounds

Description: Highly saturated colors on dark backgrounds create optical vibration. Tone down all UI colors in dark mode by reducing saturation and increasing lightness.
Do: Reduce saturation by 20-30% and increase lightness by 10-15% for all accent colors in dark mode using HSL adjustments
Don't: Use fully saturated accent colors (#FF0000/#00FF00) on dark backgrounds — they glow/vibrate and are physically uncomfortable to view

Description: Use opacity to create subtle layering in dark mode. White-with-opacity works for overlays and borders creating surfaces that adapt naturally to any base color.
Do: Use white with varying opacity for elevation: 5% for level 1 / 8% for level 2 / 11% for level 3 matching Material Design surface tints
Don't: Use fixed gray hex values for each level — they break when the base surface color changes and are harder to maintain

Description: Borders need to be visible but subtle in dark mode. Use white with low opacity or zinc-700/zinc-800 for consistent edge definition without harshness.
Do: Use #27272A (zinc-800) or white/10 for subtle borders that define edges without creating harsh visual lines
Don't: Use bright or high-contrast borders like zinc-400 or white — they dominate the visual hierarchy and create a wireframe look

Description: Horizontal dividers and separators should be barely visible just enough to indicate section breaks without adding visual clutter.
Do: Use #27272A (zinc-800) or white/[0.06] for dividers — they should be the most subtle element in the hierarchy
Don't: Use the same divider color from light mode or high-contrast lines that visually chop the interface into rigid sections

Description: Box shadows are nearly invisible on dark backgrounds. Replace shadows with subtle border or lighter surface backgrounds to communicate elevation.
Do: Replace shadows with subtle borders (border-zinc-800) or lighter backgrounds for elevation since shadows on dark surfaces are invisible
Don't: Keep the same shadow values from light mode — they are invisible on dark backgrounds and provide no elevation cue wasting render effort

Description: WCAG requires a minimum 4.5:1 contrast ratio for normal text and 3:1 for large text. Verify all text-background combinations in dark mode meet these thresholds.
Do: Test all text-background pairs with a contrast checker; primary text on base should be at least 12:1 and secondary at least 4.5:1
Don't: Eyeball contrast without measuring — many combinations that look fine to one user fail for users with low vision or in bright ambient light
Code Example Bad:
/* zinc-500 on zinc-900: ~3.4:1 ratio */

/* fails AA */

Pattern: Avoid Pure White on Pure Black
Description: Pure white (#FFFFFF) on pure black (#000000) creates a 21:1 ratio which causes halation — the text appears to bleed into the background for many users.
Do: Use off-white (#E5E5E5 to #F2F2F2) on dark gray (#121212 to #1A1A1A) for a comfortable 13-16:1 ratio that is accessible without causing halation
Don't: Use #FFFFFF on #000000 — the maximum 21:1 contrast causes text to glow and swim particularly for users with astigmatism (roughly 50% of the population)

Description: For long-form reading and dashboard interfaces slightly reduce contrast to minimize eye fatigue during extended viewing sessions.
Do: Use zinc-300 (#D4D4D8) on zinc-950 for long-form text providing ~11:1 ratio that is highly accessible yet comfortable for sustained reading
Don't: Use maximum contrast for all text regardless of context — reading interfaces at high contrast for long periods causes eye strain and headaches

Description: Icons and glyphs need sufficient contrast but often serve as secondary information. Use slightly reduced contrast compared to primary text while staying above 3:1.
Do: Use zinc-400 (#A1A1AA) for decorative icons and zinc-300 for interactive icons ensuring 3:1 minimum for non-text elements per WCAG 2.1
Don't: Use the same color as disabled text for active icons — users cannot tell which icons are interactive versus decorative
Code Example Bad: <svg class='dark:text-zinc-600'> /* too dim for interactive icons */

Description: Status colors (red/green/yellow/blue) must be adapted for dark mode. Use lighter tints of each to maintain meaning and contrast on dark surfaces.
Do: Use lighter tints: red-400 for errors / emerald-400 for success / amber-400 for warnings / blue-400 for info — all maintaining 4.5:1 on dark surfaces
Don't: Use the same status colors from light mode (red-600/green-600) — they lose contrast and vibrancy on dark backgrounds and fail accessibility checks
Code Example Bad: Error /* low contrast on dark bg */

Description: Bright images on a dark interface create jarring contrast. Slightly reduce brightness and increase contrast of images to blend better with the dark surroundings.
Do: Apply a subtle brightness reduction (85-90%) and slight contrast increase to images in dark mode using CSS filters
Don't: Leave images at full brightness — they act like flashlights on the page drawing disproportionate attention and causing discomfort

Description: Hero and banner images with text overlays need darker gradients in dark mode to maintain text readability without the light-mode gradient looking out of place.
Do: Use a darker gradient overlay (from black/70 to transparent) on hero images in dark mode ensuring text remains legible
Don't: Use the same light-mode overlay gradient which often goes from white/50 — this creates a washed out gray appearance on dark interfaces
Code Example Bad: <div class='bg-gradient-to-t from-white/50 to-transparent'> /* looks gray in dark mode */

Description: SVGs using hardcoded fill or stroke colors will not adapt to dark mode. Use currentColor or CSS custom properties to make SVGs theme-aware.
Do: Use currentColor for fills and strokes then control color via the parent text color class so SVGs automatically adapt to dark mode
Don't: Hardcode fill='#000000' or fill='#333' in SVGs — they become invisible on dark backgrounds and require manual overrides per icon

Description: Provide a dark-mode variant of your favicon so it remains visible in browser tabs when the system or browser uses a dark theme.
Do: Use SVG favicon with prefers-color-scheme media query inside it or provide both light and dark PNG favicons with media attribute
Don't: Use only a dark-colored favicon — it becomes invisible in browser tabs when the user has dark mode enabled in their OS
Code Example Bad: <link rel='icon' href='/favicon.ico'> /* single dark icon invisible in dark tab bar */

Description: Buttons need distinct visual treatment in dark mode. Primary buttons should use toned-down brand colors; secondary buttons should use subtle borders or low-opacity fills.
Do: Use desaturated brand color (blue-500) for primary / zinc-800 with zinc-200 text for secondary / and white/5 hover states for ghost buttons
Don't: Keep light-mode button styles unchanged — light gray secondary buttons disappear against dark surfaces and bright primaries look neon
Code Example Good: <button class='dark:bg-blue-500 dark:hover:bg-blue-400 dark:text-white'> <button class='dark:bg-zinc-800 dark:text-zinc-200 dark:hover:bg-zinc-700'>
Code Example Bad: <button class='bg-gray-200 text-gray-800'> /* invisible in dark mode */

Description: Form inputs need explicit dark mode styling. Dark backgrounds with subtle borders and light placeholder text ensure usability and visibility.
Do: Use zinc-900 background with zinc-700 border / zinc-100 text / zinc-500 placeholder / and zinc-600 ring on focus for inputs
Don't: Rely on browser defaults or use white backgrounds for inputs in dark mode — they create blinding spots that break the visual flow
Code Example Bad: <input class='bg-white border-gray-300'> /* white box on dark page */

Description: Cards in dark mode need coordinated background/border/and content color treatment. The card should feel cohesive and elevated from the base surface.
Do: Use zinc-900 bg with zinc-800 border / zinc-100 heading text / zinc-400 body text / and hover:bg-zinc-800/50 for interactive cards
Don't: Use a card that only differs by border — without background differentiation the card feels like a bordered region rather than an elevated container

Description: Toasts and alerts need sufficient contrast with the dark surface while preserving semantic color meaning (success=green/error=red/etc.).
Do: Use dark tinted backgrounds: bg-red-900/50 with red-200 text for errors / bg-emerald-900/50 with emerald-200 text for success
Don't: Use the same light-mode alert styles (bg-red-50 with red-800 text) — they look out of place and create bright spots on dark interfaces
Code Example Bad: <div class='bg-red-50 text-red-800'> /* bright red box in dark mode */

Description: Tables with alternating rows need dark-adapted zebra striping. Use very subtle background differences and ensure borders do not overpower the data.
Do: Use zinc-950 base with zinc-900 alternating rows / zinc-800 borders / zinc-200 header text / and zinc-300 body text
Don't: Use high-contrast alternating colors or heavy borders — the table looks like a spreadsheet rather than a refined data display

Description: Dropdowns and menus appear above other content and need clear visual separation in dark mode through background/border/and shadow (or border-as-shadow).
Do: Use zinc-900 bg with zinc-800 border / subtle ring-1 ring-white/5 for depth / and zinc-800 hover state for menu items
Don't: Use the same background as the surface below — the dropdown blends in and users cannot tell where the menu begins and the content ends
Code Example Good: <ul class='dark:bg-zinc-900 dark:border dark:border-zinc-800 dark:ring-1 dark:ring-white/5'><li class='dark:hover:bg-zinc-800'>
Code Example Bad: <ul class='dark:bg-zinc-950'> /* same as page bg / no separation */

Description: The initial dark mode state should respect the user's OS-level color scheme preference using the prefers-color-scheme media query.
Do: Check prefers-color-scheme on first visit and apply the matching theme; allow manual override that persists via localStorage
Don't: Ignore system preference and default to light mode — users who set dark mode system-wide expect your app to follow automatically

Description: Once a user manually selects a theme store that preference so it persists across sessions and page loads without flashing the wrong theme.
Do: Store theme preference in localStorage and apply it synchronously in a blocking <script> in <head> to prevent flash of wrong theme (FOWT)
Don't: Store preference only in React state or a cookie that loads asynchronously — this causes a visible flash of light mode on every page load for dark mode users

Description: When toggling between light and dark mode apply a brief CSS transition to all color properties to prevent jarring instant switches.
Do: Add a global transition (150-200ms) on color/background-color/and border-color when theme changes then remove the transition class to avoid interfering with other animations
Don't: Apply permanent transitions on all elements — this slows down every interaction and causes colors to lag during scrolling and hovering
Code Example Bad: * { transition: all 300ms } /* permanent transition on everything / performance nightmare */

Description: Offer a three-way toggle: Light / Dark / and System (auto). The System option syncs with OS preference in real-time via matchMedia listener.
Do: Provide Light/Dark/System options; System mode adds a matchMedia change listener that updates the theme when the OS preference changes
Don't: Only provide Light/Dark toggle without System option — users who change OS theme throughout the day must manually toggle your app each time
Code Example Bad: /* only two options: light/dark / no system sync */

Description: On OLED/AMOLED displays truly black pixels (#000000) are turned off completely consuming zero power. Dark mode with large black areas can save 30-60% display power.
Do: Offer an OLED mode using #000000 for large surface areas (base bg / sidebars) while keeping elevated surfaces slightly lighter for hierarchy
Don't: Use dark gray (#121212) everywhere including on OLED mode — while comfortable it does not achieve the battery savings that motivate many OLED users to use dark mode
Code Example Bad: /* no OLED optimization / same dark gray on all displays */

Description: Dark backgrounds reduce the energy needed for pixel rendering on most displays and can reduce GPU paint time for large gradient or animated areas.
Do: Use solid dark colors for large surfaces instead of gradients to reduce paint complexity; reserve gradients for small accent areas
Don't: Use complex dark gradients or animated dark backgrounds as base surfaces — they increase GPU paint time and battery usage on mobile
Code Example Bad: <main class='dark:bg-gradient-to-br dark:from-gray-900 dark:via-slate-900 dark:to-zinc-900'> /* heavy gradient base */

Description: Use CSS custom properties (--color-*) as design tokens for theming. This enables instant theme switching without class-based overrides on every element.
Do: Define all theme colors as CSS custom properties in :root and .dark then reference them throughout the app — theme changes update instantly via one class toggle
Don't: Hardcode Tailwind dark: variants on every single element — this bloats HTML / increases bundle size / and makes theme changes require touching every component
Code Example Bad: /* 20+ dark: classes per component across hundreds of elements */

Description: Approximately 50% of people have some degree of astigmatism causing bright text on dark backgrounds to appear blurred (halation). Avoid pure black backgrounds and pure white text.
Do: Use #121212 to #1A1A1A backgrounds with #E5E5E5 text; this reduces halation while maintaining excellent contrast for users with astigmatism
Don't: Use #000000 background with #FFFFFF text — the extreme contrast exacerbates halation making text appear to spread and blur for roughly half of all users
Code Example Good: <body class='dark:bg-zinc-950 dark:text-zinc-200'> /* zinc-950=#09090b soft and accessible */

Description: Users with dyslexia can find extremely high contrast more difficult to read. Offer a reduced-contrast reading mode or ensure body text uses slightly softened colors.
Do: Provide a comfortable default (zinc-300 on zinc-950 ~11:1) and optionally a high-contrast mode for users who need it — accommodating both dyslexic and low-vision users
Don't: Only offer maximum contrast with no alternative — this forces dyslexic users to endure uncomfortable reading conditions with no recourse
Code Example Good: <article class='dark:text-zinc-300'> /* ~11:1 ratio comfortable default */ /* optional: .high-contrast .dark article { color: #F5F5F5 } */
Code Example Bad: <article class='dark:text-white'> /* forced 21:1 on black / no option to reduce */
